Peter, it will probably take some time to have well-researched answers
to t=
his kind of question, but here is my guess for the moment:  First,
novelty =
search may have a tendency to avoid stagnation already because
it includes =
the current population along with the archive when it
measures novelty.  So=
 in effect, even if nothing is new historically,
the population is still re=
pelling itself away from where it is
currently.  That means that over time =
the population will kind of
dance around the behavior space until it hits a=
 stepping stone to
something different.  It could take a long time, but at =
least it will
never just sit still and "give up" the way fitness-based evol=
ution
tends to do when it converges prematurely.  Novelty search never
"fee=
ls" like it has found an optimum because it is effectively
coevolutionary a=
nd always looking to break free.

There also may be something more active w=
e can do to push it out
beyond this inherent dynamic.  Maybe there is a met=
hod of detecting
that things are not diversifying well anymore and then pus=
hing things
out.  Yet we would need to be careful because simply e.g. uppin=
g the
mutation rate might make things worse by knocking our population off
=
the current set of behaviors back to something more primitive.  Still,
sinc=
e this research direction is in its infancy, I'd guess there will
end up ma=
ny creative ideas for dealing with various bad situations,
just as people h=
ave come up with all kinds of tricks to deal with
pathologies in fitness-ba=
sed search. 

ken
